title: Hungarian science fiction
html:
Hungarian science fiction

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Hungarian science fiction comprises books and films in the fiction genre produced all across Hungary.[1]

PÃ©ter Zsoldos was a science fiction author who largely wrote about themes common in US/UK science fiction like space travel and robots. His best known work is probably Ellenpont, which translates as Counterpoint. The book explores the attempts of artificial intelligences abandoned by Man to uncover their origins and, ultimately, to rediscover mankind.[2]

Animation[edit]

  • Les MaÃ®tres du temps (lit. The Masters of Time, a.k.a. Time Masters, Az idÅ urai in Hungarian) is a 1982 Franco-Hungarian animated science fiction feature film directed by RenÃ© Laloux and designed by MÅbius. It is based on the 1958 science fiction novel L'Orphelin de Perdide (The Orphan of Perdide) by Stefan Wul.[16]
  • The Tragedy of Man (2011 film)[17][18]

Magazines[edit]

  • Galaktika (1972-1995)

Galaktika was a science fiction magazine of Hungary, published between 1972 and 1995. The peak of 94,000 copies was very high (compared to the population of Hungary [pop. 10 million] while Analog magazine was printed in 120,000 copies in the United States [pop. well over 200 million]), when reached its peak period, it was one of the largest science-fiction magazines of the world, and the quality of individual volumes was high.

A newer publication with the same name has been published since 2004 that is known for its practice of translating and publishing works without obtaining the permission of the authors and without paying them.[19]

Video games[edit]

  • Crysis Warhead (2008)

paragraphs.title: Magazines
paragraphs.text:
Galaktika was a science fiction magazine of Hungary, published between 1972  and 1995. The peak of 94,000 copies was very high (compared to the population of Hungary [pop. 10 million] while Analog magazine was printed in 120,000 copies in the United States [pop. well over 200 million]), when reached its peak period, it was one of the largest science-fiction magazines of the world, and the quality of individual volumes was high.
